title: From Courtside to Code: A Real Guide to Getting Started in Sports Analytics
description: A beginner's guide to using Python, Pandas, and Matplotlib to analyze NBA data. Learn how to visualize efficiency and scoring leaders with real code examples.
content:
If you spend as much time watching NBA highlights as I do, you’ve probably realized that the game has changed. It isn’t just about who can hit the most contested jumpers or who has the highest vertical anymore. Sports analytics has become one of the most important things when it comes to sports because it’s the only way to cut through the noise. Teams are using data to decide who to draft, how to play defense, and even when to tell a player to take a rest.

But for most people, the word "analytics" sounds like a math lecture you’d want to sleep through. I’m here to tell you it doesn’t have to be like that. You don’t need a PhD to start building your own tools. I’m going to walk you through a program I’ve been working on that takes a massive file of NBA data and turns it into something you can actually use to win an argument or manage your fantasy team better.

## Setting Up Your Environment

Before we can look at any stats, we need to get your computer ready to handle the data. We’re using Python for this because it’s basically the gold standard for data science. If you don’t have it yet, go download it from the official site.

Once you have Python, you need a few "libraries." These are just external toolkits that give Python extra powers. We are going to use **Pandas** to handle our data tables, **Matplotlib** to draw our graphs, and a little tool called **adjustText** so our labels don't look like a cluttered mess.

You’ll want to open your terminal or command prompt and type this in:

```bash
pip install pandas matplotlib adjustText
```

If you get stuck here, just search for "how to install pandas" on YouTube. There are thousands of one minute videos that will show you exactly where to click. It’s the easiest part of the process, but it’s the foundation for everything else we’re going to do.

## The Data: Our Raw Material

For this project, we are working with a JSON file called `2025-26.NBA.Roster.json`. Think of a JSON file as a giant, organized list of everything a player has ever done. It’s got their height, their weight, and every single stat from every season they’ve played.

Our goal is to take this huge, messy file and filter it down so we only see what happened in the 2025 regular season.

### Step 1: Loading and Cleaning the Mess

The first part of our code is all about organization. We start by importing our tools and writing a function to open that JSON file.

```python
import json
import pandas as pd

def load_nba_data(file_path, season=2025):
    with open(file_path, 'r') as f:
        data = json.load(f)
```

Inside this function, we create an empty list called `rows`. We are going to loop through every player in the file and grab their name. Then, we look through their "stats" section. We only care about the year 2025 and we want to make sure we aren't looking at playoff stats yet, just the regular season.

```python
    rows = []
    for p in data['players']:
        name = p.get('name') or f"{p.get('firstName', '')} {p.get('lastName', '')}".strip()
        
        for s in p.get('stats', []):
            if s['season'] == season and not s['playoffs']:
                rows.append({
                    'Name': name,
                    'Points': s['pts'],
                    'Assists': s['ast'],
                    'Rebounds': s['orb'] + s['drb'],
                    'Minutes': s['min'],
                    'Games': s['gp']
                })
    return pd.DataFrame(rows)
```

At the end of this, we return a Pandas DataFrame. If you’ve ever used Excel, a DataFrame is basically just a spreadsheet that lives inside your code. It makes it incredibly easy to sort players by who has the most points or who played the most minutes without having to scroll through thousands of lines of text manually.

### Step 2: Visualizing the Data

Now that we have a clean table, we need to make it look good. Looking at a list of numbers is boring. We want to see trends.

I wrote a second function called `plot_nba_stats` that does two things. First, it calculates "Per Game" stats. Total points are cool, but they don't tell the whole story if one guy played 82 games and another only played 40.

```python
def plot_nba_stats(df, stat_name):
    per_game_col = f"{stat_name} Per Game"
    df[per_game_col] = df[stat_name] / df['Games']
    
    top_10 = df.sort_values(by=per_game_col, ascending=False).head(10)
```

After we find the top 10 players for whatever stat we choose, we use Matplotlib to draw two graphs side by side. The first graph is a simple bar chart. It’s great for seeing who the absolute leaders are in a specific category. But the second graph is where the real analytics happen. It’s a scatter plot that compares Minutes Played against the Total Stat.

## Interpreting the Results

When you run this program, you get two visuals that immediately tell a story.

In the first image, the bar chart on the left shows the scoring leaders. This is what you see on ESPN every day. But look at the scatter plot on the right. This is "Efficiency" in action.

If a player is way up in the top left corner, it means they are putting up massive numbers despite not playing as many minutes as the stars. If they are in the bottom right, they are playing a ton of minutes but not producing much. This is how you find the "underrated" players who deserve more playing time.

In this second shot, we added labels for specific legends like LeBron James and Steph Curry. It’s interesting to see where the veterans land compared to the young guys in the league. You can see how LeBron’s output compares to his minutes, which helps you understand how he’s managing his workload at this stage of his career.

## Why You Should Care

The reason I love this stuff is that it takes the bias out of the game. We all have players we like and players we hate, but the numbers don't have a favorite team. By writing just a few lines of Python, you can start asking your own questions.

You could easily change the code to look at "Blocks" instead of "Points" to see who the real defensive anchors are. Or you could calculate "Points per Minute" to see who the best bench scorers are in the league.

This is just the tip of the iceberg. Once you get comfortable with Pandas and Matplotlib, you can start looking at "True Shooting Percentage" or "Usage Rate." You’re not just a fan anymore, you’re an analyst.

If you want to try this yourself, I’ve got the full code ready to go. Just grab your data, install your dependencies, and start coding. Let me know what kind of weird stats you find or if you have ideas on how to make the efficiency plots even better. Happy hunting.

title: The NFC East: A Division in Transition
description: A deep dive into the coaching carousel and competitive landscape of the NFC East heading into 2026, featuring insights on the Eagles, Commanders, Cowboys, and Giants.
content:
Thank you to Ameya Idate for writing this article.

As the NFL regular season winds down, a strange silence has settled over the playoff bracket. For the first time since 2017, the postseason will not feature Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, or Joe Burrow. While most of the attention is on the Lombardi Trophy hunt, one division in particular stands out as a focal point for change: the NFC East.

### The Philadelphia Eagles
They finished 11-6, but they are grappling with a sudden identity crisis. After losing offensive coordinator Kellen Moore to Kevin Patullo, the unit has regressed. Despite having **Saquon Barkley** and the elite receiving duo of **A.J. Brown** and **DeVonta Smith**, the run game essentially collapsed, losing nearly 40 percent of its rushing yardage per game.

### The Washington Commanders
Coming off a disappointing 5-12 season, the organization is hitting the reset button. While head coach **Dan Quinn** remains, the team is parting ways with offensive coordinator Kliff Kingsbury and defensive coordinator Joe Witt Jr. This team is no longer just looking to compete; they are looking to prove they weren't one-hit wonders with **Jayden Daniels**.

### The Dallas Cowboys
The Cowboys continue to be the league's mark of mediocrity, finishing 7-9-1. Statistically, Dallas has one of the best offenses, ranking 1st in yards per game with **Dak Prescott** and **George Pickens**. However, the defense lacked stability, leading to the firing of defensive coordinator Matt Eberflus.

### The New York Giants
New York moved on from head coach Brian Daboll midseason. After losing **Malik Nabers** and **Cam Skattebo** to injuries, the team fell off. However, rookie quarterback **Jaxon Dart** exceeded all expectations, and **Abdul Carter** emerged as a promising edge rusher. With a top 5 draft pick on the way, the pieces are there for a quick turnaround.

title: The Impact of Analytics: Beyond the Box Score
description: An exploration of why raw scoring isn't everything in the NBA. Comparing the offensive gravity of stars like Zach LaVine to the 'glue' impact of role players.
content:
Imagine you are an NBA general manager and you have to choose between two players. Player A averages 20 points; Player B averages 10 points. If you look at the box score, Player A is the one getting the headlines. But if you look at the win column, everything flips.

### The Case for Efficiency
In the 2023 season, **Zach LaVine** often saw the Bulls play better while he was on the bench, carrying a negative 18.8 On/Off rating. Meanwhile, **Alex Caruso** was the heartbeat of the team, maintaining a positive net rating with almost every teammate he shared the floor with.

### The Engine Problem
The 2021 Brooklyn Nets are the ultimate cautionary tale. Having **Kevin Durant**, **James Harden**, and **Kyrie Irving** seemed like a cheat code. The problem is that a basketball game only has one ball. When you have three players who all need a 30 percent usage rate, you reach diminishing returns.

### The Glue Guys
Compare the Nets to the 2021 Milwaukee Bucks. They replaced Eric Bledsoe with **Jrue Holiday**. While Holiday's raw scoring numbers weren't always massive, his defensive presence was suffocating. He won possession after possession on the margins. Analytics has taught us that surrounding a superstar like **Giannis** with hyper-efficient connectors is more valuable than adding a second high-volume, low-defense scorer.

title: The First Post: Setting Up the Site
description: A quick look at the process of building this minimalist, weather-reactive portfolio using React and Tailwind.
content: Welcome to my new personal site. This project was born out of a desire for a clean, typography-focused space to share thoughts on sports, data, and media.
